clinical_study.brief_title: Prevention of Sleep Apnea After General Anaesthesia With a MAD
clinical_study.official_title: Prevention of Sleep Apnea After General Anaesthesia With a Mandibular Advancement Device: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Sleep apneic episodes increase after general anaesthesia up to the third postoperative night. A mandibular advancement device, called MAD, is a small device that is inserted in the patient's mouth during the night and allows the advancement of the mandible, preventing sleep apneic episodes. The objective of this randomized controlled trial is to determine whether a MAD reduces the impact of general anaesthesia on the increase of the sleep apneic episodes in the postoperative period. All patients will have their sleep-related respiratory data measured using a portable respiratory polygraphy recorder (ResMed Embletta® system). This portable recorder allows a non-invasive recording of nasal airflow through a nasal cannula, oxygen saturation (SpO2) via finger pulse oximetry, respiratory efforts through thoracic and abdominal belts, and body position.

primary_outcome.description: Apnea-Hypopnea index in the supine position

secondary_outcome.description: Gobal Apnea-Hypopnea index: the number of apnoea and hypopnoea per hour of recording
Obstructive apnoea index: the number of apnoea from an obstructive origin per hour of recording
Central apnoea index: the number of apnoea from a central origin per hour of recording
Hypopnea index: the number of hypopnoea per hour of recording
Obstruction desaturation index: number of oxygen desaturation (≥3%) episodes per hour of sleep.

arm_group.description: Patients will have a mandibular advancement device during the first postoperative night

intervention.description: Patients will have a mandibular advancement device during the first postoperative night

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adult patient undergoing any lower limb surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment for obstructive sleep apnoea,
- presence of severe respiratory or cardiovascular disease
- preoperative consumption of benzodiazepine,
- chronic use of opioids > 30 mg/day morphine equivalent
- no tooth
- patient known for malignant hyperthermia
